node.title: Pearl Harbor veteran, 101, recalls dramatic escape from warship
node.description: "Those darn torpedoes, they just kept hitting us and kept hitting us. I thought they'd never stop," U.S. Navy Seaman 1st Class David Russell said.

node.title: China Nears a Reckoning as Property Firms Face Tough Deadlines
node.description: Evergrande and Kaisa must come up with hundreds of millions of dollars in days. Beijing sought to reassure markets overall, but signaled it might let Evergrande fail.

node.title: Bitcoin plunges in weekend trading, with markets facing renewed volatility.
node.description: Investors have pulled back broadly from risky assets as financial markets have been struck by the arrival of the Omicron variant and surprisingly high inflation.

node.title: San Francisco Restaurant Apologizes for Asking 3 Police Officers to Leave
node.description: The uniformed officers had just sat down when staff members asked them to leave because the workers felt uncomfortable about the officers’ weapons, the restaurant said.

node.title: China Warns of 'Countermeasures' If Biden Admin. Boycotts Winter Olympics
node.description: The diplomatic boycott is not a full one—meaning it wouldn't prevent U.S. athletes from competing in the Winter Games.

node.title: Aung San Suu Kyi is in jail, so what led to the former icon of Myanmar's pro-democracy movement being imprisoned?
node.description: Aung Sang Suu Kyi is set to spend the next four years behind bars in a case widely seen as contrived and dismissed by critics as a farce, but the 76-year-old Nobel Prize winner, who faced international criticism for her government's treatment of the country's mostly Muslim Rohingya minority, remains a controversial figure.

node.title: What a former CDC director says about Omicron
node.description: Former acting CDC Director Dr. Richard Besser, pediatrician and president of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, weighs in on the latest COVID-19 variant.

node.title: Makayla Noble Update As Paralyzed Cheerleader's Hand Nerve Pain Worsens
node.description: A fundraiser set up to help with the 17-year-old Texas resident's medical expenses has surpassed $200,000 in donations.

node.title: Donald Trump Says He Would Not Have Survived If James Comey Kept FBI Job
node.description: The former president fired Comey as FBI Director in 2017, amid the Mueller investigation into accusations of Russian collusion in the 2016 election.

node.title: Burglar Chased Off Property by Homeowners Ends up Crashing Getaway Car Into Tree
node.description: The thief was caught in the act by the homeowners when they returned to the property.

node.title: Conch shell DNA leads to charge against pallbearer at victim's funeral
node.description: Investigators determined that injuries to the victim's face had been caused by the spiny exterior of the conch shell, and testing of the interior revealed a full DNA profile.

node.title: A Terrible Catch-22
node.description: Should wrongfully convicted people falsely admit guilt to win parole?

node.title: Water Gushes From Tree Being Cut Down in Viral Video Viewed Over 13M Times
node.description: Michael Adams, who posted the video, said the water had been pouring out for a minute before he started filming.

node.title: Taliban declares women "free," not "property," but nobody celebrates
node.description: Activists protest as the U.S. says "much more is needed" than the extremist group's formal "decree" that a woman is "not a property" and can't be forced into marriage.

node.title: Russia and India Sign Military Agreement Despite U.S. Threat of Sanctions
node.description: The U.S. has warned its partners against purchasing Russian military equipment if they wish to avoid sanctions under a 2017 law.

node.title: J.&J. booster works well for people who had Pfizer originally, study finds.
node.description: A small study in Boston looked at mixing and matching with the third shot.

node.title: Patek Philippe’s Nautilus Watch Returns in Tiffany Blue
node.description: There will be only 170 of the special Ref. 5711 models so, the company’s president said, deciding who gets them may be “a big problem.”

node.title: Thailand reports its first case of the Omicron variant, in a U.S. citizen visiting from Spain.
node.description: A U.S. citizen who entered the country nearly a week ago received his first positive test result on Dec. 1. Thailand has pushed to reopen to tourists, aiming to revive its economy.

node.title: David Perdue and Brian Kemp's Brutal GOP Brawl Is Good News for Stacey Abrams in Georgia
node.description: David Perdue lost his Georgia Senate seat in a runoff against Democrat Jon Ossoff in January.

node.title: Kitten Trapped in Drain for a Week Rescued by Arizona Firefighters
node.description: The Phoenix Fire Department took two days to rescue the tiny and defenseless animal from a deep city sewer.

node.title: Chanel Builds a New Home for 11 of Its Specialty Creators
node.description: Feather concoctions and elaborate embroideries are among the marvels now being made at 19M, a seven-level complex in Paris.

node.title: The Okavango Blue Diamond, and a Lesson in Geology
node.description: Visitors to the American Museum of Natural History may be attracted by glitter, but scientists see more in the unusual stone.

node.title: Accessories in Johannesburg: Five Looks
node.description: The population of South Africa’s largest city is diverse, and so are the ways that residents choose to adorn themselves.

node.title: The Best Thrillers of 2021
node.description: They may be (relatively) low on body counts, but the year’s most chilling, atmospheric reads will still set your pulse racing and your heart pounding.

node.title: Best Movies of 2021
node.description: Even when a film wasn’t great, filmgoing was. But there were some truly wonderful releases, ranging from music docs and musicals to westerns and the just plain weird.

node.title: Opioids Feel Like Love. That’s Why They’re Deadly in Tough Times.
node.description: America can’t arrest its way out of a problem caused by the fundamental human need to connect.

node.title: Why Humans Aren’t the Worst (Despite, Well, Everything Happening in the World)
node.description: The historian Rutger Bregman makes a case for the “collective brilliance” of humanity.

node.title: We Are Not Going to Run Out of Hypocrisy Anytime Soon
node.description: Yet another school shooting, the Supreme Court argument over Roe and much else in American life gives us pause.

node.title: A Glimmer of Justice in Death Penalty States
node.description: The halting of executions and the guilty verdicts in the Ahmaud Arbery case have given us the slightest bit of hope for change.

node.title: New York Religious Schools Face a Vaccine Mandate. Will They Fight It?
node.description: Mayor Bill de Blasio set a vaccine mandate for religious and private schools. Jewish and Catholic leaders are frustrated, and some have predicted legal challenges.
